newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW - Microsoft CFO on spending.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Microsoft CFO on spending.

text.p: Microsoft Corp will spend more than $500 million, or 25 percent of its research and development budget for the current fiscal year, on media efforts such as its on-line service and MSNBC news venture, a top executive said Thursday.

Microsoft Chief Financial Officer Mike Brown said in an interview that the remaining 75 percent of the company's $2.1 billion R&D budget for the year ending June 30, 1997, is reserved for projects related to the company's core businesses of computer operating systems and desktop applications.

Earlier Microsoft officials said they planned to spend $100 million in the current fiscal year on marketing the MSN on-line service, which they did not expect to become profitable for at least three years.
In addition, the software giant has committed $230 million over five years, in addition to its $220 million initial investment, in the MSNBC cable television and Internet news venture.
"We're making an investment. It's a very serious investment. It'a very important investment," Brown said. Still, he said, it was not yet "clear whether they would become profitable."
"It's an evolving business model," he said. "But the business model for software wasn't clear 21 years ago when our company was started."
He emphasized that the company relied on its "strong billing engines" of desktop applications and operating systems, and poured the bulk of its R&D spending back into those businesses.
And he acknowledged that the on-line ventures represented "a big bet."
"That's why it's great to have Bill," he said, referring to Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates. "He's good at making big bets."
